subject: Re: On PALM
msgSnippet: ... This is an extremely good point. But I believe it is actually because Utter is terribly overloaded representing 1. unstressed indefinite vowels and 2.
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>For example, QS spells the word "arrest" Ado-Roar-Ed-Sis-Tut.
>The first three vowels can be confusing, since a reader doesn't know if
>Ado goes with Roar to give the same sound in NURSE, or, if it stands
>alone so that Roar goes with Ed.
>...
>Anyway, I'm just trying to point out that the vowel before Roar
>situation needs to be discussed a bit more.
>

This is an extremely good point. But I believe it is actually because
Utter is terribly overloaded representing 1. unstressed indefinite
vowels and 2. sampa /V/ and 3. part of the "ligature" for NURSE.

Thus the problem may not be with the vowel+Roe arrangements per se but
with Utter in particular. (I believe the "Ed-Roar vs Age-Roar" issue
you mention is merely because Et and Eight before Roe are ambiguous
for everyone.)

The first Shaw alphabet had separate letters for vowels + Roe just as
you suggest but they introduce a whole new set of very serious
problems. I'm certain this is why Read abandon them in QS. I think
fixing Utter will fix the apparent problems with vowels + Roe and
several other issues.
